source.title: Attacking Your Weakest Link

tactical_insights.text: fixing what's actually broken
burning cash on expensive ads
because you haven't read enough books or attended enough conferences
This isn't rocket science
fix what's actually broken
broken in your company

key_quotes:
by overhauling your sales process? If your team is a disaster, why would you focus on implementing new reporting metrics?

The methodology is straightforward:

Take the assessment (it takes less than 6 minutes) or find another that looks across all the areas of your business

Identify your strongest area (nice job, pat yourself on the back)

Pinpoint your weakest area (this is what you attack first)

Develop a focused plan to address ONLY that area first

This isn't rocket science.

source.title: The Human Bottleneck Killing Your Growth

tactical_insights.text: "the economy" or "AI disruption" or whatever excuse is trending on Twitter this week
doing the work that actually moves the needle
industry changes every quarter now
done it this way" person charges

key_quotes:
throwing money at new tools and start asking harder questions about the person using them:

When's the last time they suggested an improvement you hadn't thought of?

Do they talk about results or activities when reporting progress?

Are they learning new skills or coasting on old ones?

Would they survive at a high-growth company for six months?

Define your non-negotiables: measurable outcomes per month (give them a number), process improvements (make it trackable), and speed of execution (how fast can they implement and iterate?).
playing whack-a-mole with tactics.

asking harder questions about the person using them:

Define your non-negotiables: measurable outcomes per month (give them a number), process improvements (make it trackable), and speed of execution (how fast can they implement and iterate?).
